definition: Any of the set of observable characteristics of an organism resulting from the interaction of its genotype with the environment.
Processes relating to metabolism and growth.
The percentage of guanine (G) and cytosine (C) bases in a DNA or RNA molecule, often used as an indicator of stability and gene expression potential in a sequence.
material entity; An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.
The temperature range at which an organism exhibits the most efficient growth and biological activity. This is typically the mid-range temperature between the maximum and minimum limits for growth.
Optimal growth pH of a microbe
The temperature range at which an organism exhibits the most efficient growth and biological activity. This is typically the mid-range temperature between the maximum and minimum limits for growth.
The temperature range at which an organism exhibits the most efficient growth and biological activity. This is typically the mid-range temperature between the maximum and minimum limits for growth.
An organism or virus or viron that is too small to be viewed by the unaided eye.
A chemical entity is a physical entity of interest in chemistry including molecular entities, parts thereof, and chemical substances.

A population growth phenotype relating to how the rate and/or extent of growth of a microbial population is affected by the pH of the environment.; This is a high-level term whose primary purpose is to organize terms beneath it in the ontology, and we expect that it will not be used for direct annotations. Please consider using a more specific term to annotate each phenotype.
source_label: pH effects on population growth phenotype

definition: Changed hyperosmotic salinity response.
The ability of an organism to survive and grow in the presence or absence of oxygen, ranging from obligate aerobes to obligate anaerobes, as well as facultative anaerobes.
aerobic organism; an organism that can survive and grow in an oxygenated environment
microaerophilic organism; an aerobe that can grow at oxygen levels lower than what is present in the atmosphere
facultative anaerobic organism; an anaerobe that makes ATP by aerobic respiration if oxygen is present, but is capable of switching to fermentation if oxygen is absent.
an aerobe that requires oxygen to grow
an anaerobe that cannot grow in the presence of oxygen
facultative anaerobic organism; an anaerobe that makes ATP by aerobic respiration if oxygen is present, but is capable of switching to fermentation if oxygen is absent.
an anaerobe that can tolerate low levels of oxygen
an anaerobe that can tolerate low levels of oxygen
facultative aerobe; A microbial phenotype that describes a microorganism that does not require oxygen gas (O2) for growth but will utilize O2 in metabolic reactions when it is present.
A population growth phenotype where growth of a microbial population can occur at 0 C and optimal growth occurs at temperatures of 15 C or lower.
Mesophile; A mibrobial organism that thrives at moderate temperature, typically between 20 and 45 C (68 and 113 F).
Thermophile; A microbial organism that thrives at relatively high temperatures, between 45 and 122 C (113 and 252 F).
Hyperthermophile; A subset of obligate thermophiles for which optimal growth temperatures are above 80C.

Psychrotrophic microbes are cold-tolerant bacteria or archaea that can grow or even thrive in a cold environment although their optimal growth temperatures are between above 15 C and below 20 C. Their maximal growth temperatures are below 20 C.
The ability to survive a period of exposure to extremely high temperature (heat shock).
Basophile; Alkalophile; Alkaliphile; Alkalinophile
an anaerobe that can tolerate low levels of oxygen
A process occurring in living organisms.
A process during which a living entity acquires or generates food and energy from a living, dead, or non-living entity.
A function which inheres in a living entity by virtue of that entity being able to harvest energy and create biomass from non-living materials.
A chemoautotroph which is capable of using a biogenic organic compound as an electron donor.
A chemoautotroph which is capable of using a biogenic organic compound as an electron donor.
A chemoheterotroph which is capable of using an abiogenic organic compound as an electron donor.
A chemoautotroph which is capable of using an abiogenic organic compound as an electron donor.
A chemoheterotroph which is capable of using an abiogenic organic compound as an electron donor.
A chemotrophic phenotype where energy is obtained from the oxidation of inorganic chemicals.
A chemoheterotroph which is capable of using a biogenic organic compound as an electron donor.
A function which inheres in a living entity by virtue of that entity being able to feed on living or once-living (dead) material.
An organism which is capable of heterotrophic and autotrophic trophic processes.
Water which has very low concentrations of nutrients.
A trophic process during which a living entity acquires reducing equivalents from organic chemicals for use in biosynthesis or energy conservation via aerobic or anaerobic respiration.
A photoheterotroph which is capable of using a biogenic organic compound as an electron donor.
organotroph; A chemotrophic phenotype where energy is derived from the oxidation of organic molecules.
shape of cell; The shape of a cell.
bacillus; A cylindrical cell phenotype where an organism has rod-shaped cells.
spherical-shaped; A spheroid cell phenotype where a cell is spherical or nearly spherical.
crescentic; bow-shaped; lunate
A cell arrangement phenotype where an organism forms pairs of coccus cells, which arise from a division event in one plane.
A concave 3-D shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having two parts, roughly spherical and of equal size, connected by a bar.
ellipse-shaped; ellipsoid; elliptical; oval; ovoid
Flask; flask; A container with a base wider than the narrow neck traditionally used for holding liquids.
spiral; helical; helicoid; helicoidal; helix-shaped
egg-shaped; oval; ovoid; eccentric
Pleomorphic-shaped; Pleomorphic
annular; ring-shaped; A shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having a shape like a ring (a circular shape enclosing a space).
rod-like; rod-shaped; tubulate
orb; A cell morphology phenotype in which a cell is formed in the shape of a sphere.
spiral; helical; helicoid; helicoidal; helix-shaped
stellate; A shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being arranged like rays or radii; radiating from a common center.
A spiral cell shape phenotype where a rod-shaped cell is curved to form a comma-like shape or incomplete spiral.
sub-coccoidal; subspherical; subcoccoidal
disc-shaped; disk-shaped; A shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being cylindrical, in which the height is less than the diameter.
Having a spindle-like shape that is wide in the middle and tapers at both ends.
A shape quality inhering on a bearer by virtue of a bearer's shape lacking in pattern or uniformity; for example, it may have sides of different lengths, different curvatures, or unequal angles.
A spiral cell shape phenotype where a cell forms a flexible spiral.
square face shape; square faces; square facial shape
shape of tail; The shape of a tail.
deltoid; delta shaped; triangle; triangle-shaped

Gram staining is a method for staining and identifying bacteria. It is based on the differential retention of a crystal violet-iodine complex within the cell membrane. The cell wall of gram-positive cells have a thick peptidoglycan layer that retains crystal violet after an alcohol wash (staining black-blue or purple by a counterstain). The cell wall of gram-negative cells have a thinner peptidoglycan layer that does not retain crystal violet after an alcohol wash (staining red after counterstain). Some cells have variable staining in culture (e.g. Bacillus, Clostridium) while others have indeterminate staining due to unique aspects of their cell membrane or wall (e.g. Mycobacterium, Mycoplasma).
Bacteria that retain the crystal violet stain used in Gram staining. Gram-positive bacteria have a thick peptidoglycan layer in their cell walls.
Bacteria that do not retain the crystal violet stain used in Gram staining. Gram-negative bacteria have an outer membrane and are often resistant to certain antibiotics.

The ability of cells to move by themselves using mechanisms such as flagella, cilia, or pseudopodia. Motility is an important characteristic for distinguishing microorganisms and understanding their behavior.
A cell that moves by its own activities.
A sperm cell that is not cabaple of motion (motility).
A motile sperm cell that contains a slender threadlike microscopic appendage that enables motion.
cell gliding motility; Cell motility that results in the smooth movement of a cell along a solid surface.
A habitat characterized by an average temperature of at least 80deg C. Inhabited by hyperthermophilic organisms.
The ability to utilize specified substances as nutrients.
The number of breaths taken by an organism per unit of time.
The enzymatic release of energy from inorganic and organic compounds (especially carbohydrates and fats) which requires oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor.

The enzymatic release of energy from inorganic and organic compounds (especially carbohydrates and fats) which uses compounds other than oxygen (e.g. nitrate, sulfate) as the terminal electron acceptor.
respiratory-chain phosphorylation

electron acceptor activity; electron donor activity; electron carrier; electron transporter activity; A molecular function representing the directed movement of electrons from one molecular entity to another, typically mediated by electron carriers or acceptors, resulting in the transfer of energy and/or the reduction-oxidation (redox) transformation of chemical species. This activity is fundamental to various biological processes, including cellular respiration and photosynthesis, as well as numerous enzymatic reactions involved in metabolic pathways.

methane biosynthesis from methanol; methane biosynthetic process from methanol; The formation of methane, a colorless, odorless, flammable gas with the formula CH4, from other components, including methanol.
acetoin metabolism; The chemical reactions and pathways involving acetoin, 3-hydroxy-2-butanone, often as part of a fermentation pathway or for use as a carbon source.

The process whose specific outcome is the progression of a spore over time, from its initiation to the mature structure. A spore is a structure that can be used for dissemination, for survival of adverse conditions because of its heat and dessication resistance, and/or for reproduction.
length of cell; The length of a cell.
width of cell; The width of a cell.
length of cell; The length of a cell.
A width which is relatively small.
width of cell; The width of a cell.
width of cell; The width of a cell.

normal cell population growth in presence of sodium chloride; normal cell population growth on sodium chloride; normal growth on NaCl; normal vegetative cell population growth on sodium chloride; normal cellular response to sodium chloride; A phenotype in which vegetative cell population growth is normal (i.e. indistinguishable from wild type) in a medium containing sodium chloride, usually at a higher level than in standard media.
Optimal growth pH of a microbe
high blood oxygen saturation level
oxygen content with high oxygen concentration
The anaerobic enzymatic conversion of organic compounds, especially carbohydrates, coupling the oxidation and reduction of NAD/H and the generation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP).
Optimal growth pH of a microbe
An affinity inhering in an anatomical structure by virtue of the bearer exhibiting a molecular interaction for acidic dyes under specific pH conditions.
an anaerobe that can tolerate low levels of oxygen
The accumulation of pigment in an organism, tissue or cell, either by increased deposition or by increased number of cells.
